title: 109_s3662
content: The Credit Monitoring Enhancement Act of 2006 may be cited as the "Credit Monitoring Enhancement Act of 2006" and clarifies issues related to credit monitoring. The Credit Monitoring Enhancement Act of 2006 clarifies that certain credit monitoring services are not considered activities under the Credit Repair Organizations Act. The Credit Monitoring Enhancement Act of 2006 clarifies that credit monitoring services, including projections and forecasts of potential credit scores, analysis of actual or hypothetical credit scores, and assistance for identity theft victims, are not considered activities under the Credit Repair Organizations Act. The Credit Monitoring Enhancement Act of 2006 specifies that credit monitoring services cannot claim to modify accurate credit information or conceal adverse information in a consumer's credit report. The Credit Monitoring Enhancement Act of 2006 prohibits credit monitoring services from claiming to modify or remove accurate credit information from a consumer's credit report. If inaccurate information is found, it can be corrected but cannot be removed. If inaccurate information is found in your credit report, you have the right to dispute it by contacting the credit bureau directly. You also have the right to obtain a free copy of your credit report once every 12 months from each of the nationwide consumer reporting agencies. To request your free credit report, fill out the Annual Credit Report Request Form or mail it to the Annual Credit Report Request Service in Atlanta. Additional copies can be obtained from a credit bureau for a fee, but no fee is charged if you've been denied credit, employment, insurance, or housing due to your credit report within the last 60 days. The credit bureau must offer assistance in interpreting your credit file. You are entitled to a free credit report if you are unemployed, receive public welfare assistance, or suspect fraud. You can cancel a credit monitoring service without penalty and receive a pro rata refund if prepaid. The Federal Trade Commission regulates these rights. The Federal Trade Commission regulates credit bureaus and credit monitoring services. Consumers can cancel a credit file monitoring program at any time without penalty. Contact the Federal Trade Commission for more information. The Credit Repair Organizations Act allows for pro rata refunds of prepaid subscription fees upon cancellation by the consumer. Additionally, there are clarifications on nonexempt status and revisions to disclosure requirements under the Act. The Credit Repair Organizations Act allows for pro rata refunds of prepaid subscription fees upon cancellation by the consumer. You have the right to dispute inaccurate information in your credit report directly with the credit bureau. Accurate, negative information can only be removed after 7 years, while bankruptcy information can be reported for 10 years. You can request a free copy of your credit report annually from each nationwide consumer reporting agency. To request a free copy of your credit report, call 322-8228 or mail the Annual Credit Report Request Form to: Annual Credit Report Request Service, P.O. Box 105281, Atlanta, GA 30348-5281. Additional copies can be obtained from a credit bureau for a fee. No fee is charged if you were denied credit, employment, insurance, or housing due to your credit report within the last 60 days. Free reports are available if you are unemployed and seeking employment, receive public welfare assistance, or suspect fraud in your report. If there is inaccurate information in your credit report due to fraud, you have the right to sue a credit repair organization that violates the Credit Repair Organization Act. You can cancel your contract with any credit repair organization within 3 business days. Credit bureaus must ensure accurate information but mistakes can happen. You can dispute inaccurate information in your credit file by notifying the credit bureau in writing. If the credit bureau's reinvestigation does not resolve the dispute, you can send a brief statement explaining why you think the record is inaccurate. The Federal Trade Commission regulates credit bureaus and credit repair organizations. Contact them for more information at 1-877-FTC-HELP or visit www.ftc.gov.
